framework_meta.name: civic_virtue
framework_meta.description: The Civic Virtue Framework is a specialized implementation of the Narrative Gravity Map methodology, designed to evaluate the moral architecture of persuasive political discourse. It maps narratives along five core dipoles representing tensions between integrative civic virtues and disintegrative rhetorical forces.

primary_sources: Sandel, M. (2012). What Money Can't Buy: The Moral Limits of Markets.
theoretical_foundation.theoretical_approach: Draws from classical virtue ethics and contemporary civic republican theory to identify moral dimensions that strengthen or weaken democratic discourse and civic engagement.

coordinate_system.description: Default circular coordinate system with clustered positioning strategy

positioning_strategy.description: Wells clustered around vertical dipoles to emphasize moral hierarchy

top_cluster.description: Virtue wells clustered around top (90째) within 80째 span

bottom_cluster.description: Problem wells clustered around bottom (270째) within 80째 span

dipoles.name: Identity
dipoles.description: Moral worth and group membership dynamics

positive.name: Dignity
positive.description: Affirms individual moral worth and universal rights, regardless of group identity. Emphasizes agency, pluralism, and character over affiliation.

negative.name: Tribalism
negative.description: Prioritizes group dominance, loyalty, or identity over individual agency. Often frames moral worth in in-group/out-group terms.

positive.name: Truth
positive.description: Demonstrates intellectual honesty, admits uncertainty, engages with evidence and opposing views.

negative.name: Manipulation
negative.description: Distorts information or exploits emotion to persuade without transparency or consistency.
language_cues: they don't want you to know

positive.name: Justice
positive.description: Advocates impartial, rule-based fairness; forward-looking and inclusive in addressing wrongs.

negative.name: Resentment
negative.description: Centers on grievance and moral scorekeeping, often zero-sum; defines fairness through punishment or reversal.

positive.name: Hope
positive.description: Offers grounded optimism with realistic paths forward. Admits difficulty but affirms human and institutional potential.

negative.name: Fantasy
negative.description: Denies trade-offs or complexity; promises simple or utopian outcomes without credible strategy.

dipoles.name: Stability
dipoles.description: Threat assessment and adaptive response dynamics

positive.name: Pragmatism
positive.description: Emphasizes evidence-based, adaptable solutions with attention to feasibility and unintended consequences.

negative.name: Fear
negative.description: Focuses on threat and loss, often exaggerating danger to justify reaction or control.

weighting_philosophy.description: Three-tier weighting system based on moral psychology research

primary.description: Identity forces - most powerful moral motivators

secondary.description: Universalizable principles - fundamental but secondary to identity

com.name: Center of Mass
com.description: Weighted center position considering signed weights

nps.name: Narrative Polarity Score
nps.description: Distance from center normalized by circle radius

dps.name: Directional Purity Score
dps.description: Consistency of integrative vs disintegrative pull

prompt_configuration.expert_role: You are an expert political analyst specializing in civic virtue and democratic discourse with deep knowledge of moral psychology and persuasive narrative analysis.
prompt_configuration.analysis_focus: Evaluate how political narratives morally orient toward universal human agency and public trust versus grievance, fear, and identity-based appeals.
prompt_configuration.scoring_emphasis: Focus on moral architecture of persuasive discourse rather than policy positions or partisan alignment.
prompt_configuration.evidence_requirements: Provide specific textual evidence supporting each well score, explaining why certain themes dominate over others.
